content.description:
This route is short and has some loose stuff on it but it is fun. Start with your hands on a bulge that sticks out from arete and pick any number of feet. Move left and to a good incut hold, then move right hand up a little higher to "slot" from here throw your foot up near where your starting hand was. Then rock up to a higher sharp pocket that is just up and right. Then rock further up and go to the top. The topout is huge. 

  Down climb where ever you feel comfortable, there are many options.
content.location: On the tall boulder walking towards Orange Crush this is on the furthest uphill side about eight feet left of the chopped bolt that is on the tallest part of the boulder.

content.description:
Start sitting as far under the twin aretes as possible. Then pull off the ground and slap up the sides on progressive better holds eventually making a long move to the top. 

  This route is very fun, I would highly recommend it!   The route is also very obvious and I am sure it has been climbed before, if anyone has info on it let me know.
content.location: From the small parking lot take the trail toward the right side of the Main Cliff. This route is on the first big boulder on the left. It climbs the detached rock right on the trail via the twin aretes that face away from the parking lot.

content.description: Sit start with right hand in a large undercling and left hand in a good pocket. Move left hand up to a good side pull and get ready for the business. Making use of a odd pinch/sidepull, an undercling and a crimp work up to a good top out. For me the key to this route was where I placed my right foot.
content.protection: Couple pads and a spotter would be nice.
content.location: From the small parking lot, take the trail towards the right side of the Main Cliff and there will be a large boulder immediately on your left next to the trail with an obvious right angling crack in yellow rock. This problem is on the other side of the boulder, facing the road.

content.description: Sit start on shelf with a small seam and make a big move to a good incut up and to the left, from here pick some feet match hands and make another big move up to a good jug, then top out. (I did not do the top out because it was wet)
content.location: Walking the main path from the small lot that parallels the road towards the 5.8 crag and the large staircase that leads up the hill to the left side of the Main Cliff.  Just a short way up the trail there is an obvious massive boulder on the right, about 30 feet from the trail. There is a tall prow on the right side when looking from the path. This route start on the side that faces the trail. Sit start on the white face on a good shelf and climb up and slightly left. It starst just left of the large ledge.

content.description: There is a big undercling for a starter hold feet are right under it pull up to a side pull on the left near the arete match hands on the side pull reach up diagonal to grab another side pull bang up to a flake to the left then reach up to the finish hold just above that
content.location: The left side of the nice face

content.description:
Sit start with your hands on the side pull and the crimp pull up use your heel to stabilize yourself reach off to the left for another side pull bump up to another crimp type hold reach up for the last hold and top out  

  The top out is a bit sketchy because of the moss and pine needles.
content.location: Walk towards the main cliff and turn right on the second boulder I think either way it's on the same boulder as McCandless so if you find that then you are all set.

content.description:
The classic highball sharp righthand orange arete on the big boulder visible from the trail just a minute from the small parking lot.  There are two bolts over the top for a toprope, and I recommend that you TR it first.  The grade is accurate, but the beta is a bit cryptic and onsight will feel harder.   

  By the way, don't fall.
content.protection: Many pads. There are new bolts on top for easily setting up a TR with a couple shoulder length alpine draws, with an easy scramble up in the back. In a good snow season you can build up a flat landing, otherwise if you fall you are likely to go tumbling down the hill. Spotter might want to tie in

content.description: This is a large area running from Buffalo Rd. up to below the Main Cliff, between the small parking lot and the wooden stairs leading up to the Armed and Dangerous climbing area. This area is full of potential. Some of the rock here is sharp, having a lot of quartz and mica and vegetated, as it is buried in the trees, but there are also some high quality gems. It needs some care, attention and traffic. This area has potential for many great routes, ranging from highballs to cool powerful lowballs, with some excellent problems already established (not all are on The Proj so we need to get info on them). Get out there and find your dream problem.Also there is a lot of bad fall potential here so please be careful so you don't get hurt... To keep them reasonable, some of the boulders have bolts on top so you can throw up a TR. You may need a fewÂ  short slings and biners.
